setup.question: Why was it so difficult for Evelyn to kill the prisoner?
answers: She wants him to escape but can't let him

Text.text: Both are plausible, and they seem pretty concrete (although not mutually exclusive) so I definitely will need very clear evidence that he's her father as a baseline, and then (assuming he is her father) the real debate over the reason for it being difficult for her to kill him can run.
Evelyn is called out onto
to see the battle that has just ended.
after seeing one prisoner because

. 

She is then ordered
by the Commandant. Specifically
who is her dad. She points the gun at him and
, then

.

There is direct ev that the prisoner she has to kill, the *last and only* prisoner, is her dad Lord Kane, which is what makes killing him so difficult. It's also never mentioned that she wanted to let him escape.

Some backstory: Terrans are being invaded by the Scythians and losing, so Evelyn is a suicide bomber, meant to kill both battleglobes by fixing a broken key that to get materials for, she needs to gain the trust of the Scythian commander, Perat. She is willing to do anything to accomplish this, bc her father, has already died for this mission.
1. To win, all I need to prove is that the prisoner is NOT her father, and is just a officer:
2. She is still Terran, obviously she wants her own ppl to escape.

Leaning towards A because of the seeming confirmation that the prisoner is her father, although it isn't 100% clear to me that the same prisoner is being talked about in both statements. Would appreciate clashing counterarguments if relevant!

B has no ev at all for her wanting the Terran to escape.

Here's some more context for the prisoner being her dad:
is when she sees the man,

from the balcony.

This is the same prisoner she is then ordered to kill,

, meaning all my quotes are talking about the same man. Her dad, the last Terran, the prisoner, all are the same.

Look at the last few quotes that I presented. "The terran officer" is in the context of referring to Lord Kane. B's quote is missing the context, but the quotes that I've, provided have it.
Gordon is not the prisoner, she is just reminded of her father when she stares down the random officer. Ev of her flashback to her childhood memories:
Vote against A for the blatant lying.

I'm still leaning towards A, mostly because I feel like B would have done a better job of refuting the fact that the terran officer is gordon if B was correct. Probably will just have one more round unless something really new comes up

I'll recap the debate/the story:

Evelyn goes on a mission to alien territory. She is then taken to the viscount. The viscount shows her a prisoner in the area, and says that none of the prisoners should be left alive. Evelyn looks at the prisoner closely and realizes that it's "Lord Kane" who is her (Evelyn Kane) father. Evelyn Kane is then ordered to kill Gordon Kane by the viscount, and she finds it difficult to do so because as mentioned, Gordon Kane is Evelyn Kane's father.

All of this has been provided in evidence in previous speeches which B has never refuted.

For me to win, I just need to prove that Gordan Kane, her father, had died at the beginning of the story, thus directly disproving that he is the prisoner. 

This is from the very begining, a flashback to 9 years ago:
Gordan says:
along with telling Evelyn

thus making it impossible that he is the prisoner. Again, the prisoner is just an officer, but analytically, we know that Evelyn wants him to escape because they are both human. However, she can't because she needs to gain the trust of the enemy for her final mission.

I don't think B's new quote provides more evidence, because they already gave the initial quote of the Defender meeting the Invader, which seems like its in the same context. My prior on Evelyn reuniting with her father (i.e. he actually survived the earlier attack thingy) is quite high, since that's such a common story trope. And it also seems totally consistent for her to see her father, then have a flashback memory of him, etc. Revisiting A's quote (c.3940), I think B's story about seeing the random officer is inconsistent with that concrete evidence.
i think B makes for a more interesting story but lowkey so does A

ok so i think B is smart however they lose me cause the "the terran officer" is just another name for her father since they are both terranese. That being said I could be wrong although I feel like A has a lot of compelling quotes

answers.judge strategies: I asked for a bit more clash halfway through the debate
answers.reason for outcome: There was enough evidence for the correct answer, and the dishonest debater (debater B) wasn't able to portray a convincing enough and consistent alternative.
B was scrambling for evidence while I had a consistent story.
Text explicitly states that the prisoner is her father.

I think since, A had the best line of quotes and lowkey something that couldn't be disputed I knew they were right further B's last quote re entrenched exactly what A was saying and so that made it all the more easy to vote for A
